dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, you know, we see this all the time, right? People, colleagues, students even, they get super excited about a new project, and they just… jump ship from the old one.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, you know, we see this all the time, right? People, colleagues, students even, they get super excited about a new project, and they just... jump ship from the old one.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In many cases, I see my colleagues and students enthusiastically take on new projects by quickly moving away from their old projects without properly ending them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, totally! Like, before the old one is even, um, properly put to bed. It's like they just abandon it, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, totally! Like, before the old one is even, um, properly put to bed. It's like they just abandon it, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And what happens then, uh, is those unfinished projects can really drag down the new stuff you're trying to do. It's like a ghost in the machine.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And what happens then, uh, is those unfinished projects can really drag down the new stuff you're trying to do. It's like a ghost in the machine.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, projects that are not completed with strategic considerations and planning in mind may drag down new projects in many different ways.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure. So, we've gotta talk about how to actually close a project effectively. There are, like, six key steps to really nail it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure. So, we've gotta talk about how to actually close a project effectively. There are, like, six key steps to really nail it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Here are six of the steps you can follow to close your projects effectively.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, first up, it's all about that checklist. You know, Murphy's Law: "Anything that can go wrong, will go wrong." A good checklist helps you avoid a whole train of problems at the end.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, first up, it's all about that checklist. You know, Murphy's Law: "Anything that can go wrong, will go wrong." A good checklist helps you avoid a whole train of problems at the end.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Preparing a checklist for your work Murphys law states, Anything that can go wrong will go wrong! In order to avoid a train of challenges arriving during the last stage of your project, it is important to develop a final checklist.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right. And for that checklist, the article suggests this "3-W approach," which I think is great. What were your strategic objectives and did you hit them? Where were the challenges and did you address *those*? And when did you plan to hit benchmarks versus when you actually delivered?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. And for that checklist, the article suggests this "three-W approach," which I think is great. What were your strategic objectives and did you hit them? Where were the challenges and did you address those? And when did you plan to hit benchmarks versus when you actually delivered?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The 3-W approach can be very helpful for working on your checklist, as you list the three major W-questions: What [what the most strategically important objectives of the project were and what you achieved to address these], Where [where were the most pressing challenges and if you addressed all of them], and When [when you should achieve your major benchmarks in working on your project and if you realized all your deliverables].

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's super smart. Then, uh, second, you've gotta identify your target audience. It's not just you and your team knowing it's done.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's super smart. Then, uh, second, you've gotta identify your target audience. It's not just you and your team knowing it's done.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Identifying your target audience It is not enough that you and your team members know about ending the project and delivering the final product (be it a business plan, a smart phone app, college assignment or industrial prototype, etc.).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, not at all! [interrupts] You've gotta tell *everyone* – partners, clients, investors. You don't want an angry investor popping up later, like, "Hey, what happened to that thing?"
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, not at all! You've gotta tell everyone - partners, clients, investors. You don't want an angry investor popping up later, like, "Hey, what happened to that thing?"
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: From the long-term planning perspective, it is imperative that all your partners, clients, stakeholders, investors and supporters know about the successful closure of the project and about your achievements along the way. Nobody wants an angry customer or especially an investor to pop up at the last moment, unaware that you have already closed the project but forgot to inform her/him and thus technically did not complete all requirements.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! Which leads us to step three: your communication strategy. In this "information century," your message can get lost so easily.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Which leads us to step three: your communication strategy. In this "information century," your message can get lost so easily.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Developing your communication strategy and choosing communication tools In the information century, it is essential that your message about your project and your projects product(s) dont get lost among other messages, press releases and presentations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. So, choosing the right tools and strategy is crucial. Make sure people actually *know* about your success.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. So, choosing the right tools and strategy is crucial. Make sure people actually know about your success.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Therefore, you should choose your communication strategy and communication tools wisely so that more people, potential stakeholders and investors and especially your friends and colleagues know about the successful completion of the project and delivered results.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. And then, reporting your project, especially B2B. Presenting those achievements to partners or clients? Still super important.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. And then, reporting your project, especially B2B. Presenting those achievements to partners or clients? Still super important.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Reporting your project B2B Throughout our lives, we handle many projects and move from one project to another, thus it is important to make a smooth and appropriate transition from one project to the next. Effective project managers always personally present the main achievements of their completed project to all their current and potential partners and clients in a public event or even a series of public events.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's funny, these "old-school" presentations, even online ones, they really haven't gone out of fashion. You still need that personal touch.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's funny, these "old-school" presentations, even online ones, they really haven't gone out of fashion. You still need that personal touch.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Paradoxically, the old traditional ways of B2B personalized presentations or lately even online B2B presentations have not gone out of fashion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And then, of course, step five: cyberspace. We live online now, so you need to make sure your project's outcomes are properly presented and stored online, too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And then, of course, step five: cyberspace. We live online now, so you need to make sure your project's outcomes are properly presented and stored online, too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Presenting your project in cyberspace... As more and more people search for and find information online, it is essential to identify proper databases, apps, websites or other platforms to present and store the outcomes of your projects in cyberspace.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, LinkedIn, ResearchGate, whatever. [interrupts] You need to leverage those digital platforms.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, LinkedIn, ResearchGate, whatever. You need to leverage those digital platforms.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Currently cyberspace offers many opportunities from professionally run databases and data banks related to different fields to personal professional pages (e.g., LinkedIn, ResearchGate, etc.) where you can store information, reports and research data about past and present projects.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. And finally, uh, the post-project evaluation. Like, what went well, what didn't. It's like a post-mortem, but also, you know, celebrate!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. And finally, uh, the post-project evaluation. Like, what went well, what didn't. It's like a post-mortem, but also, you know, celebrate!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Conducting post-project evaluation and linking to life after the project Every textbook on project management highlights the importance of post-mortem evaluations. This step can take many forms from formal reports, to memos on lessons learned and even step-by-step evaluation of every failure or mistake, depending on the duration and scale of your project. With your final evaluation, it is important to formally and publicly close your project by celebrating with a grand party or a formal workshop.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally! Open that bottle of champagne, discuss the highlights. And even if it was tough, like Eisenhower said, "Pessimism never won any battle." Focus on the good, and use it to transition to the next thing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally! Open that bottle of champagne, discuss the highlights. And even if it was tough, like Eisenhower said, "Pessimism never won any battle." Focus on the good, and use it to transition to the next thing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This is not only an opportunity to open a bottle of champagne, but also to liven up the celebration with informal discussions with colleagues and friends about the highlights of the project, and to joke down possible tensions remaining after the end of the work. Pessimism never won any battle, Dwight Eisenhower famously said. Thus, even if your project faced many challenges and problems you should focus on the bright side of your experience in the project, creating links to life after this project or transitioning to the next ones.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, really, it's about closing strong, not just, you know, ghosting your old projects.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, really, it's about closing strong, not just, you know, ghosting your old projects.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely. It sets you up better for what's next.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely. It sets you up better for what's next.
